values.description:
This allows Gazebo to build on Windows. I followed the standard tutorial instructions, and used Windows 10.

Most the changes are minor, and are necessary due to lack of proper c++11 support on Windows.

[Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/229/), and the style errors have been fixed.
values.title: Windows_build

This allows Gazebo to build on Windows. I followed the standard tutorial instructions, and used Windows 10.

Most the changes are minor, and are necessary due to lack of proper c++11 support on Windows.

[Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/229/), and the style errors have been fixed.

values.description: Making use of what was added by pull request #2199
values.title: Plotting Palette: Refresh when models are inserted or deleted

summary.raw: Making use of what was added by pull request #2199
summary.html: Making use of what was added by pull request #2199

values.description:
1. Change the documentation to explain that deletions only need entity names rather than the whole entity SDF string. *

1. Process deletions in `World::SetState`

1. Added test


\* Referring to names is not ideal since we don't enforce unique names among models/lights for example. There was talk of changing the deletions to refer to entity ids instead, which are unique across everything that inherits from `physics::Base`. Some reasons why I stuck with names:

* It would not be ABI compatible to change the `WorldState::deletions` from string to uint

* Referring to names is compatible with [SDF](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=state#state_insertions) (even though we're not handling the SDF *yet*)

* We have a lot of other logic which deletes things by name rather than id, most notably the [`entity_delete`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d17d941637690ecf5586afd05ac581da7f515936/gazebo/physics/World.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#World.cc-1575) request, which works for models and lights.
values.title: Process deletions on World::SetState

summary.raw:
1. Change the documentation to explain that deletions only need entity names rather than the whole entity SDF string. *

1. Process deletions in `World::SetState`

1. Added test


\* Referring to names is not ideal since we don't enforce unique names among models/lights for example. There was talk of changing the deletions to refer to entity ids instead, which are unique across everything that inherits from `physics::Base`. Some reasons why I stuck with names:

* It would not be ABI compatible to change the `WorldState::deletions` from string to uint

* Referring to names is compatible with [SDF](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=state#state_insertions) (even though we're not handling the SDF *yet*)

* We have a lot of other logic which deletes things by name rather than id, most notably the [`entity_delete`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d17d941637690ecf5586afd05ac581da7f515936/gazebo/physics/World.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#World.cc-1575) request, which works for models and lights.
summary.html:
1. Change the documentation to explain that deletions only need entity names rather than the whole entity SDF string. *

  2. Process deletions in World::SetState

  3. Added test

* Referring to names is not ideal since we don't enforce unique names among models/lights for example. There was talk of changing the deletions to refer to entity ids instead, which are unique across everything that inherits from physics::Base. Some reasons why I stuck with names:

  • It would not be ABI compatible to change the WorldState::deletions from string to uint

  • Referring to names is compatible with SDF (even though we're not handling the SDF yet)

  • We have a lot of other logic which deletes things by name rather than id, most notably the entity_delete request, which works for models and lights.

values.description:
A couple of changes:

the way we're copying data to QImage isn't safe and this only became apparent when Qt tries to free the QImage which sometimes causes the double free or corruption crashes.

~~I also noticed a potential problem when using of std::unique_ptr with Qt objects, mainly that it causes a crash in the object destructor when the object goes out of scope in a non-Qt thread. I reverted the std::unique_ptr changes and just let Qt handle memory management.~~

jenkins [gpu-nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/233/) - ok
values.title: Fix ImagesView_TEST crashes

summary.raw:
A couple of changes:

the way we're copying data to QImage isn't safe and this only became apparent when Qt tries to free the QImage which sometimes causes the double free or corruption crashes.

~~I also noticed a potential problem when using of std::unique_ptr with Qt objects, mainly that it causes a crash in the object destructor when the object goes out of scope in a non-Qt thread. I reverted the std::unique_ptr changes and just let Qt handle memory management.~~

jenkins [gpu-nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/233/) - ok
summary.html:
A couple of changes:

the way we're copying data to QImage isn't safe and this only became apparent when Qt tries to free the QImage which sometimes causes the double free or corruption crashes.

I also noticed a potential problem when using of std::unique_ptr with Qt objects, mainly that it causes a crash in the object destructor when the object goes out of scope in a non-Qt thread. I reverted the std::unique_ptr changes and just let Qt handle memory management.

jenkins gpu-nvidia - ok

values.description:
Various UI updates made based on testing and user study findings. 

- Made plot title editable

- updated scroll wheel zoom (zoom in/out at cursor point instead of center of plot)

- added box select zoom (middle mouse drag) 

- removed Play/Pause bottom panel

- added a splitter to make plot size adjustable 

- enabled dragging variable to empty space in plot to start plotting

- added Show Grid option to Settings menu

- set min y-axis auto scale limits

I can break it up to smaller PRs if it helps.

jenkins [homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/251/)

  • Made plot title editable

  • updated scroll wheel zoom (zoom in/out at cursor point instead of center of plot)

  • added box select zoom (middle mouse drag)

  • removed Play/Pause bottom panel

  • added a splitter to make plot size adjustable

  • enabled dragging variable to empty space in plot to start plotting

  • added Show Grid option to Settings menu

  • set min y-axis auto scale limits

I can break it up to smaller PRs if it helps.

jenkins homebrew

values.description:
I found a minor problem related with man pages. If I'm not wrong, our cmake does not trigger the generation of `gz.1.gz` containing the updated version of the man page when we modify `gz.1.roff`.

How to reproduce the problem?

* Use a different branch, and make some change in `tools/gz.1.roff`. Run `make install` and then type `man gz`. The man page won't reflect your change unless you remove your `gz.1.gz` from your `build` directory.

This pull request should fix the problem and trigger the generation of `tools/gz.1.gz` if we modify `tools/gz.1roff`.

[trusty no gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/989/) is happy.
values.title: Fix man page generation dependecies

How to reproduce the problem?

* Use a different branch, and make some change in `tools/gz.1.roff`. Run `make install` and then type `man gz`. The man page won't reflect your change unless you remove your `gz.1.gz` from your `build` directory.

This pull request should fix the problem and trigger the generation of `tools/gz.1.gz` if we modify `tools/gz.1roff`.

summary.html:
I found a minor problem related with man pages. If I'm not wrong, our cmake does not trigger the generation of gz.1.gz containing the updated version of the man page when we modify gz.1.roff.

How to reproduce the problem?

  • Use a different branch, and make some change in tools/gz.1.roff. Run make install and then type man gz. The man page won't reflect your change unless you remove your gz.1.gz from your build directory.

This pull request should fix the problem and trigger the generation of tools/gz.1.gz if we modify tools/gz.1roff.

trusty no gpu is happy.

values.description:
I reverted a couple of changes from pull request #1980 that set the tracker min/max distance when the camera is attached to a visual. I believe the `AttachToVisual` and `TrackVisual` are separate features and should work together without affecting each other.

This problem was that when a camera sensor is created it calls `AttachToVisual` with 0 `minDist` and 0 `maxDist`. Later `track_visual` requests will cause the camera to move to the object position instead of the default 8.0m follow distance.



jenkins [homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/258/) ok
values.title: Fix camera integration test

summary.raw:
I reverted a couple of changes from pull request #1980 that set the tracker min/max distance when the camera is attached to a visual. I believe the `AttachToVisual` and `TrackVisual` are separate features and should work together without affecting each other.

This problem was that when a camera sensor is created it calls `AttachToVisual` with 0 `minDist` and 0 `maxDist`. Later `track_visual` requests will cause the camera to move to the object position instead of the default 8.0m follow distance.



jenkins [homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/258/) ok
summary.html:
I reverted a couple of changes from pull request #1980 that set the tracker min/max distance when the camera is attached to a visual. I believe the AttachToVisual and TrackVisual are separate features and should work together without affecting each other.

This problem was that when a camera sensor is created it calls AttachToVisual with 0 minDist and 0 maxDist. Later track_visual requests will cause the camera to move to the object position instead of the default 8.0m follow distance.

jenkins homebrew ok

values.description:
Fix issue number #1471

The problem seems to be related with some engine constraints.
When the simulation starts it tries to update the collisions and physics.
But Simbody doesn't generate a contactSnapshot or simulate time without a subsystem.
values.title: Fix bug when simbody is launched without any model

Fix issue number #1471

The problem seems to be related with some engine constraints.
When the simulation starts it tries to update the collisions and physics.
But Simbody doesn't generate a contactSnapshot or simulate time without a subsystem.
summary.html:
Fix issue number #1471

The problem seems to be related with some engine constraints. When the simulation starts it tries to update the collisions and physics. But Simbody doesn't generate a contactSnapshot or simulate time without a subsystem.

values.description: There are a few places in gazebo that use tinyxml symbols `TiXmlDocument` and `TiXmlElement` without including `tinyxml.h`. It still compiles because `tinyxml.h` is included in some sdformat header files (parser.hh and Converter.hh). Since only pointers are used those sdf files, the classes can be forward-declared instead of including `tinyxml.h`, which is the change proposed in [sdformat pull request 263](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/263). This pull request is necessary for gazebo to compile with that sdformat branch.
values.title: Add missing tinyxml includes

summary.raw: There are a few places in gazebo that use tinyxml symbols `TiXmlDocument` and `TiXmlElement` without including `tinyxml.h`. It still compiles because `tinyxml.h` is included in some sdformat header files (parser.hh and Converter.hh). Since only pointers are used those sdf files, the classes can be forward-declared instead of including `tinyxml.h`, which is the change proposed in [sdformat pull request 263](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/263). This pull request is necessary for gazebo to compile with that sdformat branch.
summary.html: There are a few places in gazebo that use tinyxml symbols TiXmlDocument and TiXmlElement without including tinyxml.h. It still compiles because tinyxml.h is included in some sdformat header files (parser.hh and Converter.hh). Since only pointers are used those sdf files, the classes can be forward-declared instead of including tinyxml.h, which is the change proposed in sdformat pull request 263. This pull request is necessary for gazebo to compile with that sdformat branch.

values.description:
The current actor implementation is broken (see issue [#1785](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1785/actor-does-not-render-properly)). This pull request aims to fix it and also merge the `rocon_actor` branch with `default`.

The fix can be found in `gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc`. The problem was that when the geometry of a visual was updated, its skeleton instance was not.

To manipulate an actor with a plugin, the `rocon_actor` branch introduced two new member functions `Actor::SetScriptTime()` and `Actor::ScriptTime()`. This pull request also suggests adding `Actor::SkeletonAnimations()` to get the list of all available animations for an actor, `Actor::SetCustomTrajectory()` to set its trajectory (using one of the animations), and `Actor::ResetCustomTrajectory()` to revert it back to its original state. When a custom trajectory is defined, the script time must be set by a plugin in order to play the animation.

Finally, this pull request reimplements the GUI action to show/hide the skeleton of a model or all skeletons at once.
values.title: Fix actor animation

summary.raw:
The current actor implementation is broken (see issue [#1785](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1785/actor-does-not-render-properly)). This pull request aims to fix it and also merge the `rocon_actor` branch with `default`.

The fix can be found in `gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc`. The problem was that when the geometry of a visual was updated, its skeleton instance was not.

To manipulate an actor with a plugin, the `rocon_actor` branch introduced two new member functions `Actor::SetScriptTime()` and `Actor::ScriptTime()`. This pull request also suggests adding `Actor::SkeletonAnimations()` to get the list of all available animations for an actor, `Actor::SetCustomTrajectory()` to set its trajectory (using one of the animations), and `Actor::ResetCustomTrajectory()` to revert it back to its original state. When a custom trajectory is defined, the script time must be set by a plugin in order to play the animation.

Finally, this pull request reimplements the GUI action to show/hide the skeleton of a model or all skeletons at once.
summary.html:
The current actor implementation is broken (see issue #1785). This pull request aims to fix it and also merge the rocon_actor branch with default.

The fix can be found in gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc. The problem was that when the geometry of a visual was updated, its skeleton instance was not.

To manipulate an actor with a plugin, the rocon_actor branch introduced two new member functions Actor::SetScriptTime() and Actor::ScriptTime(). This pull request also suggests adding Actor::SkeletonAnimations() to get the list of all available animations for an actor, Actor::SetCustomTrajectory() to set its trajectory (using one of the animations), and Actor::ResetCustomTrajectory() to revert it back to its original state. When a custom trajectory is defined, the script time must be set by a plugin in order to play the animation.

Finally, this pull request reimplements the GUI action to show/hide the skeleton of a model or all skeletons at once.

values.description:
Breaking pull request #2107 into smaller bits.

This makes sure the call for `physics::remove_worlds()` cleans up the world and physics engine shared pointers and properly terminates the transport topics related to that world.

* There are several calls to `reset` shared pointers in destructors which are probably not necessary, but I think there's no harm to leave them there while these issues are being fixed as a reminder of what needs to be properly cleaned up. If someone is bothered by them I can remove them.

* This branch was making the `INTEGRATION_gripper` test fail occasionally. It looks like some raw pointers have bad values by the time they're accessed on `ODEJoint::Detach`. I couldn't find the source of the problem and can't tell if it is within ODE or in the way we're using it. I was able to work around it checking if some pointers are valid before calling `dJointAttach`.

* In the process of debugging the gripper test, I also changed its implementation to use the new fixed joints instead of the old way of doing fixed joints.

[trusty no gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/269/) is :large_blue_circle:
values.title: Remove blank world

summary.raw:
Breaking pull request #2107 into smaller bits.

This makes sure the call for `physics::remove_worlds()` cleans up the world and physics engine shared pointers and properly terminates the transport topics related to that world.

* There are several calls to `reset` shared pointers in destructors which are probably not necessary, but I think there's no harm to leave them there while these issues are being fixed as a reminder of what needs to be properly cleaned up. If someone is bothered by them I can remove them.

* This branch was making the `INTEGRATION_gripper` test fail occasionally. It looks like some raw pointers have bad values by the time they're accessed on `ODEJoint::Detach`. I couldn't find the source of the problem and can't tell if it is within ODE or in the way we're using it. I was able to work around it checking if some pointers are valid before calling `dJointAttach`.

* In the process of debugging the gripper test, I also changed its implementation to use the new fixed joints instead of the old way of doing fixed joints.

[trusty no gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/269/) is :large_blue_circle:
summary.html:
Breaking pull request #2107 into smaller bits.

This makes sure the call for physics::remove_worlds() cleans up the world and physics engine shared pointers and properly terminates the transport topics related to that world.

  • There are several calls to reset shared pointers in destructors which are probably not necessary, but I think there's no harm to leave them there while these issues are being fixed as a reminder of what needs to be properly cleaned up. If someone is bothered by them I can remove them.

  • This branch was making the INTEGRATION_gripper test fail occasionally. It looks like some raw pointers have bad values by the time they're accessed on ODEJoint::Detach. I couldn't find the source of the problem and can't tell if it is within ODE or in the way we're using it. I was able to work around it checking if some pointers are valid before calling dJointAttach.

  • In the process of debugging the gripper test, I also changed its implementation to use the new fixed joints instead of the old way of doing fixed joints.

trusty no gpu is :large_blue_circle:

values.description:
On the plotting branch, the models section under search is covered by a mysterious rectangle:

![searchghost.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1421890730-searchghost.png)

This was due to an extra column magically being added to the proxy search model. It was probably happening because we were changing the original model outside of the qt thread. Moving it to signals and slots solved the problem. 

Other nice things to try here are to play with inserting and deleting models as you use the search, for example:

1. Without any box in the world, search for "box". Nothing shows. 

2. While the search is there, insert a box, and it appears in the search results. 

3. Remove the box from the world and it disappears from the search.
values.title: Plotting: Fix ghost rectangle

summary.raw:
On the plotting branch, the models section under search is covered by a mysterious rectangle:

![searchghost.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1421890730-searchghost.png)

This was due to an extra column magically being added to the proxy search model. It was probably happening because we were changing the original model outside of the qt thread. Moving it to signals and slots solved the problem. 

Other nice things to try here are to play with inserting and deleting models as you use the search, for example:

1. Without any box in the world, search for "box". Nothing shows. 

2. While the search is there, insert a box, and it appears in the search results. 

3. Remove the box from the world and it disappears from the search.
summary.html:
On the plotting branch, the models section under search is covered by a mysterious rectangle:

This was due to an extra column magically being added to the proxy search model. It was probably happening because we were changing the original model outside of the qt thread. Moving it to signals and slots solved the problem.

Other nice things to try here are to play with inserting and deleting models as you use the search, for example:

  1. Without any box in the world, search for "box". Nothing shows.

  2. While the search is there, insert a box, and it appears in the search results.

  3. Remove the box from the world and it disappears from the search.

values.description:
Issue #402

Undo / redo:

* Inserting nested models from the palette

* Copy/pasting nested models

* Deleting nested models with the DEL key

* Deleting nested models via context menu

Obs:

Model added to `testdb` should be the same as that added in pull request #2207, targeted at gazebo7. Once that is merged forward to default, they will coincide.

values.description:
confirmed that issue #1906 also affects gazebo 5 on osx and so backported fix from pull request #2221.

Added a slightly modified version of `DepthCamerSensor_TEST` from pull request #2112 that is compatible with the old depth camera behavior where 0.0f depth readings were returned if no objects are detected by the camera.

jenkins:

[gpu-nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/270/) - ok

[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/292/) - ok but dri tests don't seem to run here
values.title: Backport depth camera OSX fix and test -> gazebo5

summary.raw:
confirmed that issue #1906 also affects gazebo 5 on osx and so backported fix from pull request #2221.

Added a slightly modified version of `DepthCamerSensor_TEST` from pull request #2112 that is compatible with the old depth camera behavior where 0.0f depth readings were returned if no objects are detected by the camera.

jenkins:

[gpu-nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/270/) - ok

summary.html:
confirmed that issue #1906 also affects gazebo 5 on osx and so backported fix from pull request #2221.

Added a slightly modified version of DepthCamerSensor_TEST from pull request #2112 that is compatible with the old depth camera behavior where 0.0f depth readings were returned if no objects are detected by the camera.

jenkins:

gpu-nvidia - ok

homebrew - ok but dri tests don't seem to run here

values.description:
1. An empty search shows everything instead of nothing, which is more like a filter behaviour than a search.

1. The search terms are highlighted:

![plot_search_highlight.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3313543258-plot_search_highlight.png)

I had to move the declaration of `SearchModel` to the header to be able to use it in `PlotItemDelegate`, that's where most of the diff comes from.
values.title: Plotting: Highlight search terms and make it behave like a filter

1. An empty search shows everything instead of nothing, which is more like a filter behaviour than a search.

I had to move the declaration of `SearchModel` to the header to be able to use it in `PlotItemDelegate`, that's where most of the diff comes from.
summary.html:
1. An empty search shows everything instead of nothing, which is more like a filter behaviour than a search.

  2. The search terms are highlighted:

I had to move the declaration of SearchModel to the header to be able to use it in PlotItemDelegate, that's where most of the diff comes from.

values.description:
In c++11 the following statements are equivalent:

~~~
std::shared_ptr<Typename> x(new std::shared_ptr<Typename>(arg1, arg2));
~~~

~~~
auto x = std::make_shared<T>(arg1, arg2);
~~~

`make_shared` is more concise, but it is also [safer in certain cases](http://herbsutter.com/gotw/_102/). There is no `make_unique` in c++11 however; though it will be in c++14. In the meantime, [it is recommended](http://herbsutter.com/gotw/_102/) to include a version of `make_unique` in your own code ([dartsim has already done it](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/pull/639)). I've copied one such implementation into `gazebo/util/make_unique.hh` namespaced as `gazebo::make_unique`. The function is not declared as visible and the header file is not installed; it's just for internal use.

I've used it in a couple places, which should be a sufficient test.
values.title: Create gazebo::make_unique while we wait for c++14, use it in a few places

summary.raw:
In c++11 the following statements are equivalent:

~~~
std::shared_ptr<Typename> x(new std::shared_ptr<Typename>(arg1, arg2));
~~~

~~~
auto x = std::make_shared<T>(arg1, arg2);
~~~

`make_shared` is more concise, but it is also [safer in certain cases](http://herbsutter.com/gotw/_102/). There is no `make_unique` in c++11 however; though it will be in c++14. In the meantime, [it is recommended](http://herbsutter.com/gotw/_102/) to include a version of `make_unique` in your own code ([dartsim has already done it](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/pull/639)). I've copied one such implementation into `gazebo/util/make_unique.hh` namespaced as `gazebo::make_unique`. The function is not declared as visible and the header file is not installed; it's just for internal use.

I've used it in a couple places, which should be a sufficient test.
summary.html:
In c++11 the following statements are equivalent:

std::shared_ptr<Typename> x(new std::shared_ptr<Typename>(arg1, arg2));

auto x = std::make_shared<T>(arg1, arg2);

make_shared is more concise, but it is also safer in certain cases. There is no make_unique in c++11 however; though it will be in c++14. In the meantime, it is recommended to include a version of make_unique in your own code (dartsim has already done it). I've copied one such implementation into gazebo/util/make_unique.hh namespaced as gazebo::make_unique. The function is not declared as visible and the header file is not installed; it's just for internal use.

I've used it in a couple places, which should be a sufficient test.

values.description: The `Atmosphere_TEST` was in `gtest_sources` instead of `gtest_fixture_sources`, which was causing linking errors. The linking error was fixed in e672942, but it added unnecessary linking. This PR moves `Atmosphere_TEST` to `gtest_fixture_sources` and reverts the addition of `gazebo_test_fixture` to `gtest_sources` `EXTRA_LIBS`.
values.title: Fix EXTRA_LIBS for physics tests without ServerFixture

summary.raw: The `Atmosphere_TEST` was in `gtest_sources` instead of `gtest_fixture_sources`, which was causing linking errors. The linking error was fixed in e672942, but it added unnecessary linking. This PR moves `Atmosphere_TEST` to `gtest_fixture_sources` and reverts the addition of `gazebo_test_fixture` to `gtest_sources` `EXTRA_LIBS`.

values.description:
Fixes issue #1920

We were using a mix of link origin and "link centroid" when extending lines and placing joint visuals. This pull request removes the centroid logic completely and always uses link origins for a few reasons:

* The centroid was the average of all child visual origins, not something related to the bounding box.

* Once the joint is connected, its pose will be expressed with respect to the link origin, not a centroid. So it makes sense to also expand the line like that.

* The centroid logic was there to make things clearer in case there are many visuals in a link. But that's not clear for all cases (the centroid might end up far from all links) and we have the highlighting to indicate all the visuals in the hovered link.

Also note the use of root visual rather than parent visual, because now that we support nested models, the parent is not always the root anymore.
values.title: Model Editor: Fix line during joint creation

summary.raw:
Fixes issue #1920

We were using a mix of link origin and "link centroid" when extending lines and placing joint visuals. This pull request removes the centroid logic completely and always uses link origins for a few reasons:

* The centroid was the average of all child visual origins, not something related to the bounding box.

* Once the joint is connected, its pose will be expressed with respect to the link origin, not a centroid. So it makes sense to also expand the line like that.

* The centroid logic was there to make things clearer in case there are many visuals in a link. But that's not clear for all cases (the centroid might end up far from all links) and we have the highlighting to indicate all the visuals in the hovered link.

Also note the use of root visual rather than parent visual, because now that we support nested models, the parent is not always the root anymore.
summary.html:
Fixes issue #1920

We were using a mix of link origin and "link centroid" when extending lines and placing joint visuals. This pull request removes the centroid logic completely and always uses link origins for a few reasons:

  • The centroid was the average of all child visual origins, not something related to the bounding box.

  • Once the joint is connected, its pose will be expressed with respect to the link origin, not a centroid. So it makes sense to also expand the line like that.

  • The centroid logic was there to make things clearer in case there are many visuals in a link. But that's not clear for all cases (the centroid might end up far from all links) and we have the highlighting to indicate all the visuals in the hovered link.

Also note the use of root visual rather than parent visual, because now that we support nested models, the parent is not always the root anymore.

values.description:
There is a race condition in `~TimePanelPrivate` since the `statsSub` subscriber is defined near the top of the `TimePanelPrivate` class. This means other variables are deleted before the subscriber, which leads to seg-faults if the subscriber callback happens at the wrong time. This failure was exacerbated by adding a large delay to `~Subscriber` in 3a9e11d and was [confirmed in jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64_flaky/8/).

~~~
117: libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type
 boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::lock_error> >:
 boost: mutex lock failed in pthread_mutex_lock: Invalid argument
117/418 Test #117: UNIT_TimePanel_TEST ...................................***Exception: Other 10.24 sec
~~~

This PR changes the order of variable declarations in `TimePrivate` so that the subscriber `statsSub` subscriber and a few other variables get deleted first.

This is targeting gazebo6 and will be merged forward.
values.title: Fix race condition in ~TimePanelPrivate (#1919)

summary.raw:
There is a race condition in `~TimePanelPrivate` since the `statsSub` subscriber is defined near the top of the `TimePanelPrivate` class. This means other variables are deleted before the subscriber, which leads to seg-faults if the subscriber callback happens at the wrong time. This failure was exacerbated by adding a large delay to `~Subscriber` in 3a9e11d and was [confirmed in jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64_flaky/8/).

~~~
117: libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type
 boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::lock_error> >:
 boost: mutex lock failed in pthread_mutex_lock: Invalid argument
117/418 Test #117: UNIT_TimePanel_TEST ...................................***Exception: Other 10.24 sec
~~~

This PR changes the order of variable declarations in `TimePrivate` so that the subscriber `statsSub` subscriber and a few other variables get deleted first.

This is targeting gazebo6 and will be merged forward.
summary.html:
There is a race condition in ~TimePanelPrivate since the statsSub subscriber is defined near the top of the TimePanelPrivate class. This means other variables are deleted before the subscriber, which leads to seg-faults if the subscriber callback happens at the wrong time. This failure was exacerbated by adding a large delay to ~Subscriber in 3a9e11d and was confirmed in jenkins.

117: libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type
 boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::lock_error> >:
 boost: mutex lock failed in pthread_mutex_lock: Invalid argument
117/418 Test #117: UNIT_TimePanel_TEST ...................................***Exception: Other 10.24 sec

This PR changes the order of variable declarations in TimePrivate so that the subscriber statsSub subscriber and a few other variables get deleted first.

This is targeting gazebo6 and will be merged forward.
